i used control-o while i was transitioning from emacs land... it was a good... "crutch" for lack of a better word :) i found using esc very awkward... but all that changed when i realized i could remap esc to another key, like tab. having the esc key in a better location enables you to really use vim the way it was intended. IMHO, spending less time in insert mode will improve your productivity immensely. you do have to be willing to invest SOME time in learning badass keyboard shortcuts, though.
FWIW, another key to leave insert mode is CTRL-[. I generally use this key.

Back toward the original question a bit... yes, partly you're missing the point ;-)  But, there are a few things that can help, like Ctrl-g+j/k will move the cursor down/up a line while in insert mode, or Ctrl-w to delete back a word. Others not for moving but still nice: Ctrl-r to insert from registers, Ctrl-d/t to shift indentation. See `:h ins-special-keys` and `:h ins-special-special` for some more!
@edanm what's the 'jk' mapping command you're using?

Most insert mode mappings that use the Alt (or Meta) key seem to be pretty useless, so you can override them to suit your needs using the Ctrl-o trick mentioned above. E.g. "inoremap <m-w> <c-o>w" will remap "alt-w" in insert mode to "ctrl-o w", which will move you forward one word and drop you back to insert mode.
Documentation on key mapping, if you need more information: http://vimdoc.sourceforge.net/htmldoc/map.html#mapping
